Ernest Hemingway.passage: Ernest Miller Hemingway was an American novelist, short-story writer, and journalist. His economical and understated style—which he termed the "iceberg theory"—had a profound influence on 20th-century fiction, while his adventurous life and public image as a macho "man's man" endeared him to millions. Born in Oak Park, Illinois, in 1899, Hemingway was the second of six children. His father was a physician, and his mother was a musician. Hemingway was a high school athlete and a devotee of boxing, and he began writing for his high school newspaper. After graduation, he worked as a reporter for several newspapers before joining the Red Cross during World War I. He was seriously injured in 1918 when he was hit by a mortar shell, and he was awarded the Italian Silver Medal of Bravery for rescuing an injured soldier under fire. After the war, Hemingway moved to Paris, where he became part of the expatriate community that included Gertrude Stein, F. Scott Fitzgerald, and Ezra Pound. He published his first novel, The Sun Also Rises, in 1926, and it established him as a leading voice of the "Lost Generation" of disillusioned young people who came of age during World War I. The novel is a bleak portrait of a group of expatriates who drift aimlessly through life, unable to find meaning or purpose. Hemingway's subsequent novels, including A Farewell to Arms (1929) and For Whom the Bell Tolls (1940), explored similar themes of disillusionment, loss, and the futility of war.

William Shakespeare.passage: William Shakespeare (baptised 26 April 1564 – 23 April 1616) was an English poet, playwright, and actor, widely regarded as one of the greatest writers in the English language and the world's pre-eminent dramatist. He is often called England's national poet and the "Bard of Avon". His extant works, including some collaborations, consist of about 38 plays, 154 sonnets, two long narrative poems, and a few other verses, the authorship of some of which is uncertain. His plays have been translated into every major living language and are performed more often than those of any other playwright. Shakespeare was born and raised in Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire, England. At the age of 18, he married Anne Hathaway, with whom he had three children. He began his career in theatre as an actor, later writing and producing his own plays and forming a company called the Lord Chamberlain's Men, later known as the King's Men. At age 49 (around 1613), he retired to Stratford and died there three years later. Shakespeare's writing shows a deep understanding of human nature and a mastery of the English language. His plays are known for their complex characters, intricate plots, and vivid imagery, and have been interpreted in various ways over the centuries. They have been adapted to film, television, and stage, and have influenced literature and culture around the world. Shakespeare's works continue to be studied, performed, and enjoyed today, and his legacy remains a significant part of English and world literature.

Jane Austen.passage: Jane Austen (16 December 1775 – 18 July 1817) was an English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique and comment upon the British landed gentry at the end of the 18th century. Austen's plots often explore the dependence of women on marriage for social standing and economic security, and her works are noted for their realism and biting social commentary. Austen's novels have been adapted for film and television numerous times, and her name and image have been used for brand marketing and merchandise. Her works have also been adapted for stage, and her influence on English literature and popular culture is profound. Austen's life is not well documented, and much of what is known about her comes from her letters. She was born in Steventon, Hampshire, where her father was rector. Austen lived most of her life as part of a close-knit family with her parents, sister, and brothers. She was educated at home by her father and her brothers, and she wrote her first novel, Sense and Sensibility, when she was in her mid-twenties. Austen's novels are set in the English countryside and feature a cast of characters who are primarily members of the landed gentry. Her works often explore the social norms and expectations of the time, and the ways in which they can constrain and limit the lives of women. Austen's novels are also known for their wit and humor, and for their ability to capture the nuances of human relationships. Austen's novels have been praised for their realism and their ability to capture the social and cultural context of the time.

Fyodor Dostoevsky.passage: Fyodor Mikhailovich Dostoevsky (11 November 1821 – 9 February 1881) was a Russian novelist, short story writer, essayist, journalist and philosopher. Dostoevsky's literary works explore human psychology in the context of the troubled political, social, and spiritual context of 19th-century Russia. He is best known for his novels Crime and Punishment, The Idiot, and The Brothers Karamazov. Dostoevsky was born in Moscow in 1821, the second of seven children. His father was a former army doctor who had taken up a post as a physician in the military hospital in Moscow. His mother was the daughter of a retired army captain. Dostoevsky was educated at home by his father, who was a firm disciplinarian. He later attended the Moscow Academy of Military Engineers, where he studied engineering and mathematics. In 1849, Dostoevsky was arrested and sentenced to death for his involvement in the Petrashevsky Circle, a group of intellectuals who were critical of the Tsarist government. He was led to the execution site, but at the last moment his sentence was commuted to four years of hard labor in a Siberian prison camp. It was during his time in prison that Dostoevsky began to formulate his philosophical ideas, which would later be expressed in his novels. After his release from prison in 1854, Dostoevsky began to write fiction. His early works were influenced by the ideas of the utopian socialists, who believed that a new social order could be created through reason and human brotherhood.

George Orwell.passage: George Orwell was an English novelist, essayist, and journalist. He is best known for his novels Animal Farm and Nineteen Eighty-Four, which are considered two of the most influential works of the 20th century. Orwell was born Eric Arthur Blair in Motihari, Bengal, British India, in 1903. His family moved to England when he was one year old, and he was educated at Eton College and the University of Burma, where he served as a police officer. After leaving the police force, Orwell worked as a journalist in India and Europe, and he fought in the Spanish Civil War on the Republican side. Orwell was a committed socialist and his writing often reflected his political beliefs. He died in 1950 at the age of 46 from tuberculosis.

Virginia Woolf.passage: Virginia Woolf (1882-1941) was an English writer and one of the foremost modernists of the early 20th century. She was born in London to a well-connected family and was educated by private tutors before attending the University of London. Woolf's writing often focused on the inner lives of women and the role of women in society. She was a founding member of the Bloomsbury Group, a collective of artists and intellectuals who were known for their progressive ideas and unconventional lifestyles. Woolf's most famous works include "Mrs. Dalloway" (1925), "To the Lighthouse" (1927), and "Orlando" (1928). These novels are known for their experimental style and their exploration of themes such as memory, time, and identity. Woolf was also a prolific essayist and wrote extensively on topics such as feminism, literature, and mental health. In addition to her writing, Woolf was a prominent figure in the feminist movement of the early 20th century. She was a vocal advocate for women's rights and argued that women needed to be given greater opportunities to express themselves through literature and art. Woolf was also a suffragist and worked tirelessly to promote women's suffrage in the UK. Despite her many accomplishments, Woolf struggled with mental illness throughout her life. She was diagnosed with depression and had several breakdowns, which she wrote about in her diaries and essays. In 1941, Woolf drowned herself in the River Ouse, near her home in Sussex.

Toni Morrison.passage: Toni Morrison (born Chloe Ardelia Wofford; February 18, 1931 – August 5, 2019) was an American novelist, essayist, editor, and professor. She was the first African-American woman to be awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1993. Morrison's writing centered around the African-American experience and explored themes of race, gender, and identity. Her works included "Beloved" (1987), "Song of Solomon" (1977), and "Jazz" (1992). Morrison was also a professor at Princeton University and a member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters. She was awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2012. Morrison's legacy as a writer and advocate for social justice continues to inspire readers and writers around the world.

Gabriel Garcia Marquez.passage: Gabriel Garcia Marquez was a Colombian novelist, short-story writer, screenwriter, and journalist, known for his magical realism style of writing. He was born on March 6, 1927, in Aracataca, Colombia, and died on April 17, 2014, in Mexico City, Mexico. Garcia Marquez began his career as a journalist, working for the Colombian newspaper El Espectador and later as a foreign correspondent for the Latin American newspaper, El Tiempo. He later became a novelist and short-story writer, gaining international recognition for his works, including "One Hundred Years of Solitude" and "Love in the Time of Cholera." Garcia Marquez's writing style was characterized by magical realism, a genre that blends realistic elements with magical or supernatural elements. His works often explored themes of love, death, and politics, and were known for their vivid imagery and use of symbolism. In addition to his writing, Garcia Marquez was also an outspoken political activist, using his platform to advocate for human rights and social justice. He was awarded numerous honors and accolades throughout his career, including the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1982. Garcia Marquez's legacy continues to influence writers and readers around the world, and his works remain widely read and studied today.

J.K. Rowling.passage: J.K. Rowling is a British author who wrote the Harry Potter book series. She was born on July 31, 1965, in Yate, Gloucestershire, England. Rowling attended the University of Exeter and earned a degree in French and Classics. After college, she worked as a researcher and bilingual secretary for Amnesty International in London. In 1990, Rowling married Jorge Arantes and moved to Portugal. The couple divorced in 1993. Rowling then moved to Edinburgh, Scotland, where she began writing the first Harry Potter book. She has said that the idea for Harry Potter came to her on a train ride from Manchester to London in 1990. The first Harry Potter book, Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone, was published in 1997. It was an immediate success and has since become one of the best-selling book series in history. Rowling has written seven additional books in the Harry Potter series, as well as several books for adult readers. Rowling has won numerous awards for her writing, including the Order of the British Empire and the Hans Christian Andersen Literature Award. She has also been named a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature. In addition to her writing, Rowling is a philanthropist and activist. She has donated millions of dollars to charity and has spoken out on issues such as poverty, LGBTQ+ rights, and women's rights. Rowling has also been open about her struggles with depression and has advocated for mental health awareness. Rowling continues to write and is currently working on a new series of books for adult readers. She lives in Edinburgh with her husband and children.

Harper Lee.passage: Harper Lee (April 28, 1926 – February 19, 2016) was an American author known for her novel To Kill a Mockingbird, which was published in 1960. The novel was an immediate and immense success, winning the Pulitzer Prize, and has become a classic of modern American literature. The novel is widely read in American literature classes and is considered a masterpiece of American literature. Lee was born in Monroeville, Alabama, the youngest of four children of Amasa Coleman Lee and Frances Cunningham Finch Lee. Her father was a lawyer who served on the state legislature and was a prominent figure in Monroeville. Her mother was a homemaker. Lee was a tomboy in her youth and enjoyed playing with her older brother, Edwin. She attended local schools and then studied law at the University of Alabama. After graduating from law school, Lee moved to New York City to pursue a career in writing. She worked as an airline reservation clerk to support herself while writing. In 1957, she completed her first and only published novel, To Kill a Mockingbird. The novel is set in the 1930s in the fictional town of Maycomb, Alabama, and is narrated by the young Scout Finch. The novel explores themes of racial injustice and the loss of innocence. To Kill a Mockingbird was an immediate success and has since become a classic of modern American literature. The novel won the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1961 and has been translated into more than 40 languages. The novel has also been adapted into a popular film and a stage play. Lee never published another novel, but she continued to write.

Stratford.passage: Stratford is a town in the Stratford-on-Avon district of Warwickshire, England, and the birthplace of William Shakespeare. It is situated in the heart of England, on the River Avon, 22 miles (35 km) south east of Birmingham and 8 miles (13 km) south west of Warwick. The estimated population in 2016 was 27,445. Stratford was originally an agricultural town, but it grew in importance during the 12th century due to its position on the River Avon. The town became a centre for the wool trade and became a market town in the 12th century. In the 16th century, Stratford became a centre for the printing industry, and it was in Stratford that William Shakespeare's plays were first printed. Today, Stratford is a popular tourist destination, attracting millions of visitors each year. The Royal Shakespeare Company, which performs Shakespeare's plays, is based in Stratford, and there are several theatres in the town, including the Royal Shakespeare Theatre and the Swan Theatre. The town is also home to the birthplace of William Shakespeare, which is now a museum, and the nearby Anne Hathaway's Cottage, where Shakespeare's wife grew up. Stratford is also known for its association with the motor industry, with the British motorcycle manufacturer Triumph being based in the town. The Massey Ferguson tractor factory was also located in the town until its closure in 1981.

It is located in the North Wessex Downs, an area of outstanding natural beauty, and is about 6 miles (10 km) northwest of Basingstoke. The village has a population of around 300 people. Steventon is best known as the birthplace of Jane Austen, the famous English novelist who lived in the village from 1775 until 1801. Dostoevsky.passage: Fyodor Dostoevsky was a Russian novelist, short story writer, essayist, journalist and philosopher. His psychological penetration into the human soul and his unsurpassed understanding of human behavior have made him one of the greatest writers in the history of literature. His works have had a profound impact on modern literature and continue to be read and studied today. Dostoevsky's writing often explored the human condition, the nature of morality, and the existential questions of life. His most famous works include Crime and Punishment, The Brothers Karamazov, and Notes from Underground. Dostoevsky's writing style was characterized by its psychological depth, philosophical insight, and literary brilliance. He was also known for his social and political commentary, which often criticized the oppressive nature of the Russian government and society. Despite his controversial views and tumultuous personal life, Dostoevsky remains one of the most influential and important writers in the history of literature.

the University of Burma.passage: The University of Burma was a public university located in Rangoon, Burma (now Yangon, Myanmar). It was established in 1920 as a result of the efforts of British colonial administrators who sought to create a Western-style university in Burma. The university was modeled after the University of London and offered degrees in a range of subjects, including law, medicine, and engineering. The university was closed in 1942 during World War II and reopened in 1946 after the Japanese occupation of Burma. It was later nationalized in 1964 and renamed the University of Rangoon. The university played a significant role in the development of Burma's education system and produced many notable alumni, including Aung San, the father of modern-day Myanmar.

British India.passage: The British Raj was the period when the British Empire held suzerainty over the Indian subcontinent, from 1858 until 1947. The term "British India" refers to the period of British rule in the Indian subcontinent, which included present-day India, Pakistan, and Bangladesh, as well as parts of Afghanistan and Myanmar. The British East India Company had established trading posts in India by the late 17th century, and by the mid-19th century, it had assumed control of almost all of India. The British government took over the company's operations in 1858, following the Indian Rebellion of 1857, and India came under the direct rule of the British Crown. The British Raj was marked by a period of rapid modernization, industrialization, and economic growth, as well as by significant political and social upheaval. The Indian independence movement, which sought to end British rule and establish an independent India, gained momentum in the early 20th century, and India finally gained its independence on August 15, 1947.

qae_pairs.question: What year did the Indian Rebellion of 1857 take place in British India?
qae_pairs.explanation: The British government took over the company's operations in 1858, following the Indian Rebellion of 1857, and India came under the direct rule of the British Crown. This sentence provides a clear explanation of the events that led to the British Raj in India. It states that the British government took over the operations of the British East India Company in 1858, following the Indian Rebellion of 1857, which was a significant event that led to the end of the company's rule in India and the establishment of direct British rule.

Europe.passage: Europe is a continent located entirely in the Northern Hemisphere and mostly in the Eastern Hemisphere. It is bordered by the Arctic Ocean to the north, the Atlantic Ocean to the west, and the Mediterranean Sea to the south. It comprises 47 countries, with Russia, Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, Spain, and Poland being the most populous. Europe is the world's second-smallest continent by land area, covering about 10,180,000 square kilometres (3,930,000 sq mi) or 2% of the Earth's surface and about 6.8% of its land area. Of Europe's approximately 730 million people, about 47% are male and 53% are female. The largest country in Europe, both in terms of area and population, is Russia. The European Union, a political and economic union of 27 member states located primarily in Europe, is a major player in international affairs.

the Bloomsbury Group.passage: The Bloomsbury Group was an influential group of British writers, intellectuals, and artists associated with the Bloomsbury district of London, England, during the early 20th century. The group was centered around the Stephen family, Vanessa Bell, Virginia Woolf, and their friends, including John Maynard Keynes, E.M. Forster, and Lytton Strachey. The group was known for their bohemian lifestyle and their promotion of the arts and progressive social and political ideals. They were also associated with the Bloomsbury Diaspora, a term used to describe the dispersal of the group's members after World War II. El Espectador.passage: El Espectador is a Colombian Spanish-language newspaper based in Bogotá, Colombia. It was founded on August 14, 1911, by Jorge Eliecer Gaitán, and is considered one of the most important newspapers in the country. Mexico City.passage: Mexico City, or Ciudad de México, is the capital and largest city of Mexico. It is located in the Valley of Mexico, a large valley in the high plateaus at the center of Mexico, at an altitude of 2,240 meters (7,350 ft). The city has a population of approximately 8.8 million people, making it one of the largest cities in the world. Mexico City is an important cultural and financial center in Latin America. It has a rich history, dating back to the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan, which was founded in 1325. The city was conquered by the Spanish in 1521, and much of its architecture and culture reflects the influence of the Spanish colonial period. Today, Mexico City is a bustling metropolis with a diverse population and a vibrant cultural scene. It is home to many museums, galleries, and theaters, as well as a thriving music and nightlife scene. The city is also known for its delicious cuisine, which incorporates a blend of indigenous and Spanish flavors. Despite its many attractions, Mexico City is also facing a number of challenges. The city is located in a seismically active region, and it has been hit by several devastating earthquakes in the past. In addition, the city is plagued by traffic congestion and air pollution, which have led to health problems for many residents. Overall, Mexico City is a fascinating and complex city, with a rich history and a vibrant present. It is a must-visit destination for anyone interested in Latin American culture and history.

the Royal Society of Literature.passage: The Royal Society of Literature (RSL) is a learned society in the United Kingdom that was founded in 1820. It is dedicated to the promotion of literature and literary studies, and has a membership of around 1,000 writers, academics, and other literary figures. The society is based in London and has a library that contains over 200,000 volumes of books, manuscripts, and other materials related to literature. the University of Alabama.passage: The University of Alabama (UA) is a public research university located in Tuscaloosa, Alabama, United States, and the flagship university of the University of Alabama System. Founded in 1820, UA is the oldest and largest of the universities in Alabama. The university offers programs of study in a range of disciplines, including the arts and sciences, business, education, engineering, law, medicine, and nursing. UA is classified as a research university with high research activity by the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education. The university has produced numerous notable alumni, including Nobel laureates, Pulitzer Prize winners, and Olympic gold medalists. UA's athletic teams, known as the Crimson Tide, compete in the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I Southeastern Conference (SEC). The university's football team has won 17 national championships, and its basketball team has won 16 conference championships. UA is also known for its beautiful campus, which features historic buildings, gardens, and sculptures.
